description:
Columba livia, commonly known as the rock dove or common pigeon, is a species of bird that belongs to the family Columbidae. It is a medium-sized, stout-bodied bird with a short neck and a distinctive rounded head.

The species is native to western and southern Asia, North Africa, and parts of Europe, but has been introduced and established in many other parts of the world, including North America and Australia. Columba livia is typically found in urban and suburban areas, where it has adapted to live in close proximity to humans.

The bird's plumage is typically a bluish-gray color, with a white rump and a dark band on the tail. The wings may have iridescent feathers that appear green or purple in certain lighting conditions. Columba livia is known for its ability to thrive in diverse environments, including cities, where it has become a ubiquitous presence.

The species is an opportunistic feeder, consuming a variety of grains, seeds, and other plant matter, as well as insects and other small invertebrates. Columba livia is a prolific breeder, with the ability to produce multiple broods per year, which has contributed to its successful establishment in many urban environments.

Overall, Columba livia is a well-known and adaptable species that has been the subject of extensive research in fields such as ecology, urban wildlife management, and animal behavior.
